questions.text: A medical officer in a trauma center is evaluating a patient with a head injury following an accident. To accurately classify the injury for treatment and documentation, the medical officer needs to determine the specific criteria that constitute an open head injury. This classification is crucial in guiding the management and prognosis of head injuries. What specifically characterizes an open head injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laceration of dura

 

Option B:

 

Open Head Injury (penetrating)

 

The intracerebral lesions are divided- according to the state of dura. If the dura is lacerated, e.g., by a bullet or any other object, such as fragment of bone, it is called open injury because it is open to infection. The brain is also lacerated.

 

If the dura remains intact, it is called a closed injury, whether the skull is fractured or not. Blunt force to the head with a non-penetrating object or from a fall, or the head striking a flat surface or a firm object produce closed injuries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Skull fractures alone do not constitute an open head injury unless the dura is also lacerated.

 

Option C. Laceration of the pia mater occurs deeper within the brain and does not necessarily indicate an open head injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open head injury (penetrating): Disruption of cranial vault with opening through skin and cranial bones to expose damaged brain; most often associated missile wounds, stab/chop wounds, and motor vehicle or occupational accidents.

 

Closed head injury (non-penetrating): Damage to the brain without any fracture of the skull and/or penetration of dura; most often results from blunt trauma.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 248

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient, involved in a road traffic accident (RTA), is brought to the emergency department. The patient undergoes a head CT scan, which reveals a semilunar hyperdense lesion over the right cerebral hemisphere's parietal lobe. As a medical officer assessing the case, you need to identify the most common source of bleeding that results in this type of lesion. This determination is crucial for referral for further treatment and potential surgical intervention:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bridging veins

 

Option B:

 

The most common source of bleeding in this case, indicated by a semilunar hyperdense lesion on the CT scan over the cerebral hemisphere, is the bridging veins. The lesion described is characteristic of a subdural hematoma, which typically occurs due to the tearing of bridging veins. These veins bridge the space between the surface of the brain and the dural sinuses, and they are particularly vulnerable to shearing forces during traumatic events like road traffic accidents.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Middle meningeal artery: Rupture of this artery usually leads to an epidural hematoma, which presents differently on a CT scan.

 

Option C. Superior cerebral veins: These are less commonly involved in traumatic brain injuries compared to bridging veins.

 

Option D. Vertebral artery: Injury to this artery typically results in posterior fossa hematomas or other cerebrovascular complications, not a subdural hematoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bridging veins are the most common source of bleeding in cases presenting with a semilunar hyperdense lesion over the cerebral hemisphere on a CT scan, typically indicative of a subdural hematoma.

 

EDH - biconvex or lens shaped hemorrhage in CT scan.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 259

choices.text: Pinpoint pupils and hypothermia
Dilated pupils and hypothermia
Pinpoint pupils and hyperthermia
Dilated pupils and hyperthermia

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department after collapsing suddenly. The neurologist suspects a brainstem stroke and orders a brain MRI. The MRI reveals a pontine hemorrhage. Based on this diagnosis, the neurologist anticipates specific clinical manifestations associated with this type of hemorrhage. Which of the following characterizes a pontine hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pinpoint pupils and hyperthermia

 

Option C:

 

Pontine hemorrhages typically present with pinpoint pupils and hyperthermia. This presentation is due to the disruption of autonomic pathways in the pons, affecting both pupillary reflexes and temperature regulation. The pinpoint pupils result from parasympathetic dominance, and hyperthermia occurs due to impaired thermoregulation.

 

Pontine hemorrhages is also known as “Boxer’s hemorrhage". Retinal detachment, choroidal tears and vitreous hemorrhages may occur. Deterioration in speed and coordination is the chief symptom of the onset of punch-drunk (traumatic encephalopathy or dementia pugilistica) condition, which may arise years after the last injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypothermia is not typically associated with pontine hemorrhages.

 

Option B, Option D. Dilated pupils are more indicative of pressure on the third cranial nerve, not typical of isolated pontine hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pontine hemorrhage is characterized by 3P

 

  • Pyrexia
  • Pin-point Pupil
  • Paralysis

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 257

questions.text: In a case review at a hospital trauma center, a medical team is discussing a patient who sustained severe chest trauma in a road traffic accident. The patient has developed complications that suggest a traumatic rupture of one of the heart chambers. The team is deliberating on which chamber of the heart is most commonly involved in such traumatic ruptures. This knowledge is essential for guiding the diagnostic and surgical approach, as well as for understanding the prognosis of the injury. Which chamber of the heart is most commonly involved in traumatic ruptures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right atrium

 

Option A:

 

The right atrium is the most commonly involved chamber in traumatic heart ruptures. This is primarily due to its anterior position in the chest cavity, making it more susceptible to trauma, especially in cases of blunt chest injuries, such as those sustained in road traffic accidents. The right atrium's thin-walled structure also contributes to its vulnerability in traumatic scenarios.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Left atrium: The left atrium is less frequently involved in traumatic ruptures due to its posterior position in the heart.

 

Option C. Right ventricle: While the right ventricle is also anteriorly positioned, its thicker wall makes it slightly less susceptible than the right atrium.

 

Option D. Left ventricle: The left ventricle, being more muscular and located posteriorly, is less commonly involved in traumatic ruptures compared to the right atrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common sites of traumatic cardiac rupture in order of diminishing frequency are: right auricle, right ventricle, left auricle, ventricular septum and valves. The only natural cause of rupture of the heart is softening or thinning by infarction, which invariably occurs in the left ventricle.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 269

choices.text: Frequently occur in railway accidents
Commonly affect the cervical region
Vertebrae show extensive injuries

questions.text: In a medico-legal session, a forensic expert presents a case study on "railway spine”. The term has been used to describe certain spinal injuries and their aftermath. The faculty asked the students to identify a false statement regarding railway spine to clarify common misconceptions and update their understanding of the condition. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding railway spine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vertebrae show extensive injuries.

 

Option D:

 

"Railway spine" is a term historically used to describe a range of symptoms following a railway accident, believed to be related to the spine. The false statement is that the vertebrae show extensive injuries; in fact, railway spine was often characterized by a lack of visible spinal injuries despite the presence of symptoms.

 

Concussion of Spinal Cord (Railway Spine)

 

Causes –

 

  1. In railway and motor vehicle collisions (most common).
  2. Severe blow to the back.
  3. Compression from dislocation/fracture of vertebrae.
  4. Damage by effusion of blood.
  5. Fall from height.
  6. Bullet injury.

 

Symptoms appear immediately or after some hours and includes headache, giddiness, restlessness, sleeplessness, neurasthenia, weakness in limbs, amnesia, loss of sexual power and derangement of special senses. It produces paralysis, affecting the arms and hands or bladder, rectum or lower extremities. Paralysis is temporary and recovery occurs in about 48 h. Momentary dislocation of the spine may occur especially in the cervical region, causing crushing of the cord, followed by self-reduction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Frequently occur in railway accidents: True, as the term originated from observations of post-traumatic symptoms in railway accident victims.

 

Option B. Commonly affect the cervical region: True, Momentary dislocation of the spine may occur especially in the cervical region, causing crushing of the cord, followed by self-reduction.

 

Option C. Spontaneous reversible condition: True, Paralysis is temporary, and recovery occurs in about 48 h.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Concussion of Spinal Cord /Railway Spine is caused by railway and motor vehicle collisions (most common), Severe blow to the back, Compression from dislocation/fracture of vertebrae, Damage by effusion of blood, Fall from height and Bullet injury. Symptoms appear immediately or after some hours and includes headache, giddiness, restlessness, sleeplessness, neurasthenia, weakness in limbs, amnesia, loss of sexual power and derangement of special senses. It produces paralysis, affecting the arms and hands or bladder, rectum or lower extremities. Paralysis is temporary and recovery occurs in about 48 h.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 267

choices.text: Mixture device of bomb
Simple petrol bomb thrown by hand
Molotov, foreign minister of Russia died after having the cocktail

questions.text: During a protest in a crowded city center, an explosive device is thrown at a police barricade, causing a small but powerful explosion. This device, commonly known as a "Molotov cocktail," is characterized by?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Simple petrol bomb thrown by hand

 

Option B:

 

In this scenario, the explosive device used is a Molotov cocktail, which is a simple petrol bomb typically thrown by hand. It consists of a glass bottle filled with a flammable liquid, usually petrol/ gasoline, and a cloth wick that is lit before throwing. Its use is associated with irregular warfare or civil unrest situations.

 

Note - Incendiary bombs, e.g. napalm bombs primarily cause burns. Usually, phosphorus and magnesium are added. Temperature of 1000ºC is produced.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mixture device of bomb: This is incorrect. A "Molotov cocktail" is not a bomb in the traditional sense but rather an improvised incendiary device.

 

Option C. Molotov, foreign minister of Russia, died after having the cocktail: This is incorrect. The term "Molotov cocktail" does not refer to an actual cocktail or the manner of death of Molotov, a Soviet politician. The name is derived from Vyacheslav Molotov, a Soviet foreign minister, but it's used symbolically for the device.

 

Option D. Type of tank: This is incorrect. A "Molotov cocktail" has no relation to tanks or armored vehicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

“Molotov cocktail" is a simple hand-thrown petrol bomb used as an improvised incendiary weapon, distinct from conventional bombs or other military equipment.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 240

choices.text: Ear, lung
Kidney, spleen
Pancreas, duodenum
Liver, muscle

questions.text: During a military training exercise, an accidental explosion occurs, resulting in several soldiers being exposed to the blast. As they are evaluated at the nearby field hospital, the medical team is particularly vigilant for injuries typical of blast exposure. They understand that certain organs are more vulnerable to damage from the blast wave. In the context of this explosion, which pair of organs is most likely to be the first to sustain injury due to the blast wave?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ear, lung

 

Option A:

 

The ear and lung are the organs most susceptible to primary blast injuries.

 

The ear, particularly the tympanic membrane, is extremely sensitive to changes in atmospheric pressure and can be damaged even by mild overpressure from a blast (Acoustic Barotrauma, leading to permanent deafness).

 

The lungs are also highly vulnerable due to their air-filled structure, making them susceptible to blast wave injuries, which can lead to conditions like pulmonary barotrauma, extensive hemorrhage, systemic air embolism and free radical-associated injuries such as thrombosis and DIC, or a combination of all these — blast lung (triad of dyspnea, bradycardia and hypotension; Chest radiographs - butterfly pattern)

 

Blast lung is the most common cause of death among people who initially survive an explosion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Kidney, spleen: They are more susceptible to secondary or tertiary blast injuries, such as those caused by flying debris or the body being thrown by the blast wind.

 

Option C. Pancreas, duodenum: Injury to gas-filled viscera is more common in underwater explosions than in air blasts. Although the colon is most commonly affected, perforation of the stomach, small intestine and cecum are also seen.

 

Option D. Liver, muscle: more likely to be affected by secondary or tertiary injuries in an explosion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ear and lung are most vulnerable to primary blast effects due to their sensitivity to changes in pressure.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 239

questions.text: In the aftermath of an explosion at a fireworks factory, multiple workers suffer injuries and are brought to the emergency department. The nature of the explosion suggests a high likelihood of certain specific organ injuries. Among the injured workers from the fireworks factory explosion, which organ is most commonly affected, based on the scenario provided?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eardrum

 

Option A:

 

The eardrum (tympanic membrane) is the most commonly affected organ in explosions, particularly those involving a significant blast wave like a fireworks factory explosion. The eardrum is highly sensitive to changes in atmospheric pressure, and even a relatively mild blast wave can cause a rupture or other damage to the tympanic membrane. This makes it a frequent and immediate casualty in explosion scenarios.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Stomach: While blunt trauma in explosions can affect abdominal organs, it is less likely than injuries to more vulnerable structures like the eardrum or lungs.

 

Option C. Lungs: Lungs are susceptible to blast injuries, especially due to the blast wave's impact on air-filled structures. However, the eardrum is generally more sensitive and commonly affected due to its delicate nature and proximity to the blast wave's pressure changes.

 

Option D. Liver: Injuries to the liver would more likely result from secondary blast effects (such as debris) or tertiary effects (such as the body being thrown against a hard surface).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eardrum as the most commonly affected organ in explosion scenarios due to its high sensitivity to pressure changes.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 239

questions.text: Following an explosion on a naval vessel, several crew members sustain injuries. Some of these individuals are immersed in water after the blast, leading to concerns about specific types of injuries associated with underwater blasts. What is the most common site of injury in those who experienced underwater blast injuries, as described in the scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrointestinal tract (GIT)

 

Option B:

 

Based on the scenario involving underwater blast injuries, the most common site of injury is the gastrointestinal tract (GIT).

 

When the explosion is in the water, the pressure changes are called underwater blast. The physical changes are similar to those of explosion in air. Injuries occur mostly in the hollow organs like gastrointestinal tract (due to their air and gas content.) and less commonly in lungs. Most of the lung injury is due to pressure transmitted from abdomen through the diaphragm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tympanic membrane: While the tympanic membrane is highly sensitive to changes in atmospheric pressure and is commonly injured in air explosions. The tympanic membrane can still be affected, but it is not the most common site of injury in underwater blasts.

 

Option C. Liver: The liver, being a solid organ, is less susceptible to the immediate pressure wave effects of an underwater blast compared to gas-filled organs like the GIT or lungs. Injuries to the liver are more likely due to secondary mechanisms, such as blunt trauma.

 

Option D. Lung: Although lung injuries can occur due to underwater blasts, they are less common than GIT injuries. The lungs are susceptible to barotrauma from the pressure wave.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand that the gastrointestinal tract is the most common site of injury in underwater blast.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 239

questions.text: After a military training exercise, several soldiers report experiencing a specific combination of symptoms. This set of symptoms, known as Marshall's triad, prompts the medical team to consider the nature of the injuries sustained. Marshall's triad is associated with which type of injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Explosive injury

 

Option A:

 

Marshall's triad, which consists of bruises, abrasions, and punctate lacerations with tattooing of the body, is indicative of explosive injuries. These specific signs are often observed in individuals who have been exposed to bomb explosions. The triad reflects the unique pattern of injuries caused by the combination of the blast wave, flying debris, and the embedding of explosive material residues into the skin.

 

Flying Missiles: The blast may drive multiple fragments of bomb or pieces of nearby objects, e.g., gravel, glass, wood, brick, plaster, etc. through the air into the skin and cause bruises, abrasions and puncture lacerations intimately mixed on the skin. This triad of injury is diagnostic.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Gunshot injury: Typically present with penetrating trauma, entry and exit wounds, and tissue damage along the bullet's path.

 

Option C. Drowning injury: Drowning primarily affects the respiratory system, leading to symptoms related to hypoxia and water inhalation.

 

Option D. Lightning injury: Lightning injuries can cause a range of symptoms, including cardiac arrest, burns, and neurological effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Punctate lacerations, dust tattooing and black soiling from explosive materials may be seen. Marshall’s triad of bruises, abrasions and punctate lacerations with tattooing of the body indicates bomb explosion.

In this scenario, the abrasion is more than 7 days old. This is indicated by the presence of a partially detached scab and a depigmented area beneath it. Typically, scab formation begins soon after an injury, but the process of scab detachment and the appearance of depigmented skin beneath typically occurs after approximately 7 days as part of the healing process.

Size of the bruise

questions.text: A forensic investigator is examining a series of bruises on a victim's body. To determine whether these bruises are artificial or true bruises, which of the following characteristics would be most useful to assess?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Color changes over time

 

Option A:

 

In true bruises, the color of the bruise evolves in a characteristic pattern, starting with a reddish appearance that gradually changes to blue, purple, green, yellow, and finally fades away. This is due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and the absorption of blood pigments by different cellular components. Artificial bruises, on the other hand, might not follow this natural progression and may exhibit inconsistent color changes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Size of the bruise: The size of a bruise can provide some information about its cause. Generally, larger bruises are more likely to be associated with trauma. However, artificial bruises can also be intentionally created in various sizes.

 

Option C. Presence of underlying bone fractures: Fractures can contribute to the development of bruises, especially in true bruises resulting from trauma. However, fractures are not always necessary for bruising to occur. Artificial bruises can be inflicted without causing fractures, and some fractures might not lead to noticeable bruising.

 

Option D. Victim's medical history: While certain medical conditions can contribute to the development of bruises, both true and artificial bruises can occur regardless of the victim's medical history.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

 Difference between PM staining, True & Artificial Bruise

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being involved in a bar fight. He has sustained a wound over his forehead. During medical examination by the Casualty medical officer, Patient reports that he was punched several times. Based on the injury pattern observed, what is the most likely characterization of this wound?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laceration

 

Option C:

 

The above image is of Laceration (caused by blunt force trauma), mimicking an incision. There is presence of “tissue bridging” (arrows) and margins are contusion abraded which helps to differentiate a laceration from an incision. This is also called “Incised looking lacerated wound”. They occur at bony sites where there is thin subcutaneous tissue like Scalp, forehead, Zygoma, Iliac crest, Shin etc.

 

Laceration can be differentiated from incised wounds by following:

 

  1. Due to blunt force, there is usually associated abrasions and contusions in the margins.
  2. Depth of the wound presents bridges of irregularly torn tissue, blood vessels and nerves, etc.

 

Note - An opposite variety is Lacerated looking incised wound:  It is an incised wound, which looks like lacerated wound. It occurs in areas where skin folds are loose, like in axilla, scrotum etc. Here even an injury produced by sharp weapon appears as if it has irregular margins.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Abrasion: It is just the removal of superficial epithelial layer of the skin, whereas in image in question the deeper layers are damaged.

 

Option B. Contusion or bruise: It is the extravasation of blood in the subepithelial tissues due to rupture of blood vessels as a result of blunt force. Skin is intact in bruise, but damaged in the image in question.

 

Option D. Stab wound is produced from penetration with long narrow instruments having pointed ends into the depths of the body, and hence the depth is more than length and width. Whereas, In the image in question, the length is much more than depth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

“Incised looking lacerated wound” is a special type of lacerated wound which looks like incised wound. It occurs at bony sites where there is thin subcutaneous tissue like Scalp, forehead, Zygoma, Iliac crest, Shin etc.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 191

Stab injury of face

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with the following injuries on face. The patient is alert and oriented. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's facial injuries?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Windshield glass injury

 

Option D:

 

The image shows lacerations resembling ‘sparrow foot marks’ which are seen in motor vehicle accidents when the skin comes in contact with shattered windshield glass. The toughened glass breaks into small fragments which produce characteristic ‘sparrow foot marks.

 

Seen in people sitting in front seats in motor vehicle in road traffic accidents.

 

 

Injury sites to the Front seat passenger of the Car

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gunshot injuries: A gunshot wound can appear as a small, round entrance wound, often with an abrasion ring if the gun was fired at close range. Exit wounds are typically larger, irregular, and may have beveled edges.

 

Option B. Stab injury of face, Wound Stab wounds are typically linear or elongated, with a well-defined shape, resembling a slit or puncture. It doesn’t resemble with sparrow footmarks.

 

Option C. Vitriolage or acid attack, the resulting wound is characterized by severe chemical burns and deep tissue damage. These wounds have irregular shapes, often resembling deep craters with irregular edges. The corrosive nature of the acid causes tissue necrosis, leading to open wounds and extensive scarring as the wounds heal.

 Sparrow foot marks (Front seat passenger injuries)

 

  1. Sparrow’s foot marks are bizarre shaped lacerations that result from the face coming in contact with shattered windshield glass. The toughened glass breaks into small fragments which produce characteristic ‘sparrow foot marks.
  2. These patterns resemble the imprints of bird footprints, with multiple lines radiating outward from a central point.

questions.text: A forensic expert is called to evaluate a crime scene where a victim has committed the extensive scalping and flaying. The crime scene suggests a prolonged interaction between the assailant and the victim. In the context of criminal behavior, what is the most likely motive behind such injuries as scalping and flaying?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inflicted for Sadistic pleasure

 

Option B:

 

Some individuals commit scalping and flaying crimes for sadistic pleasure, deriving enjoyment from inflicting severe pain and harm on their victims.

 

 Avulsion injuries

 

  • Avulsion Injuries is removal of skin, and / or other tissues from their attachment
  • Flaying is a type of avulsion injury where there is a removal of large portion of skin from underlying surface. So, while avulsion refers to either skin and / or other tissues, the flaying refers mainly to skin.
  • Scalping is the avulsion injury in the scalp. In scalping there is tearing away of a portion of scalp (hair, skin and other underlying tissues) away from the head.
  • Most common cause of avulsion injury is road traffic accident
  • Other causes of avulsion injuries: machinery accidents, assaults by a sharp weapon (sadistic pleasure)
  • Most common site of avulsion injury (Flaying injury): Legs

 

 

Image shows scalping by assault

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Found in cases of Robbery: Scalping and flaying crimes are more often driven by motives related to sadistic pleasure or personal hatred rather than robbery.

 

Option C. Indicate Self-defense: Scalping and flaying injuries are not typically associated with self-defense, as they involve extreme violence.

 

Option D. Can be caused by hammer: A hammer can cause blunt force trauma but is less likely to cause a scalping injury compared to other tools like chainsaws

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avulsion injuries, such as scalping and flaying, are often inflicted by sadistic individuals who derive pleasure from causing extreme pain and harm to their victims. These injuries involve the removal of skin and other tissues from their attachments, with flaying specifically involving the removal of a significant portion of skin.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 191

choices.text: Violating the platysma layer of the neck
2 cm depth invasion
Any trauma damaging vital structure in neck
Injury by sharp object

questions.text: A 24-year-old man arrives at the emergency department following a violent altercation. He has sustained a wound to the anterior aspect of his neck. In categorizing neck trauma, which of the following definitions is accurate for penetrating neck trauma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Violating the platysma layer of the neck

 

Option A:

 

Penetrating neck trauma involves a missile or sharp object penetrating the skin and violating the platysma layer of the neck. This includes gunshot wounds, stab or puncture wounds, and impalement injuries.

 

Penetrating neck injuries remain challenging, as there are a number of important structures in a small area and injury to any of these structures may not be readily apparent.

 

The current mortality rate in civilians with penetrating neck injuries ranges from 3-6%.

 

The objects causing these injuries can be divided into stabbing instruments (eg, knives, cutting instruments, puncturing objects, impaling objects) and shooting instruments (eg, missiles, projectiles).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. 2 cm depth invasion: The depth of invasion is less important than whether the platysma layer has been breached in defining penetrating neck trauma.

 

Option C. Any trauma damaging vital structure in neck: While damage to vital structures is clinically significant, the definition of penetrating neck trauma is not contingent on whether these structures have been affected.

 

Option D. Injury by sharp object: Penetrating neck trauma can indeed be caused by a sharp object, but the definition is based on the violation of the platysma, not the object causing the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penetrating neck trauma is defined as an injury that violates the platysma layer, which is significant due to the potential for damage to critical neurovascular structures in the neck.

 

Ref:  JL Nowicki, B Stew and E Ooi. Penetrating neck injuries: a guide to evaluation and management. Ann R Coll Surg Engl. 2018 Jan; 100(1): 6–11. Published online 2017 Oct 19.

Ans. B) Direction of the wound

 

Option B:

 

Tailing of Incised wound

  • The deeper end is called head of the wound and the shallower end is called tail of the wound. This phenomenon is known as tailing of the wound.
  • Direction of the Wound is established by tailing of the wound.

Option A. Age of the wound: The tailing does not provide specific information about the age of the wound.

 

Option C. Shape of the weapon: While the overall characteristics of the wound can give some indication of the weapon's shape, tailing specifically indicates direction, not shape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tailing of the incised wound can help in determining the direction from which an incising force was applied, which can be crucial in the forensic analysis of the wound patterns in cases of assault.

Hinge fracture of base of skull
Comminuted fracture of skull

questions.text: During an autopsy of a 45-year-old male who suffered a fatal fall from a significant height, the medical officer observes a distinctive pattern of skull fracture. The base of the skull has a linear fracture extending bilaterally from the foramen magnum along the petrous ridges of the temporal bones, resembling a bilateral longitudinal separation. Given the nature of the injury and the observed fracture pattern, what is the classification of this skull fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hinge fracture of base of skull

 

Option B:

 

Image shows a transverse fracture of the base of the skull that completely splits it and divide it into two halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge (‘nodding face’ sign).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ring fracture of base of skull often seen in the skull, where the bone breaks in a circular pattern around foramen magnum. The picture above have a transverse fracture that completely splits it making it a hinge fracture, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. Comminuted fracture of skull: is when two or more intersecting lines of fracture divide the bone into three or more fragments resembling a spider web or mosaic pattern this is not the case in this picture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Depressed fracture of skull: When a portion of fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known as depressed fracture. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

‘Hinge’ # (also called Motorcyclist #): Linear fracture passes across the middle cranial fossa, separating the skull base into Ant and post halves. Occurs Severe Force to side of head (e.g. in motorcycle accidents). Such fractures are commonly associated with injuries of the brain stem, especially pontomedullary tears.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 281

questions.text: A forensic expert is presented with the skull of an infant who suffered a head trauma. Upon examination, the expert notes a fracture which is known as Diastatic fracture. The Diastatic fracture refers to fracture through?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sutural line

 

Explanation:

 

Diastatic #: Separation of cranial sutures

 

  • Seen in young children (due to non-union of sutures)
  • Causes: 1) Trauma   2) Pathology (e.g. Intracranial tumor)
  • Most commonly sagittal sutures get separated

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diastatic or Sutural Fractures: Separation of the sutures occur only in young persons, due to a blow on head with blunt weapon. It may occur alone but often is associated with fracture. It is usually seen in the sagittal suture. They are particularly common in traffic accidents. They also occur secondary to increased intracranial pressure with resulting splitting of sutures.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 247

choices.text: Ring fracture of Foramen magnum + Lumbar spine injury
Pond fracture skull + Cervical spine injury
Gutter fracture skull + Cervical spine injury
Depressed fracture skull + Cervical spine injury

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an accidental fall from a 35-foot height. Eye witnesses report that he landed on his feet. The medical officer evaluates the patient for potential injuries associated with such a mechanism of trauma. Considering the nature of the fall and the initial point of impact, which combination of injuries is the patient most likely to have sustained?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ring fracture of Foramen magnum + Lumbar spine injury

 

Option A:

 

A ring fracture of the foramen magnum is a type of basilar skull fracture that occurs circumferentially around the foramen magnum. It typically results from an axial load to the cranium, such as when a person falls from a height and lands on their feet or buttocks. This axial load is transmitted up the vertebral column to the base of the skull. Concurrently, the lumbar spine is also susceptible to injury from the same mechanism due to the compression forces that can lead to fractures or dislocations in the lumbar vertebrae.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pond fracture skull + Cervical spine injury: A pond fracture is a depressed fracture of the skull, typically caused by direct impact to the head, not by landing on the feet.

 

Option C. Gutter fracture skull + Cervical spine injury: A gutter fracture is associated with tangential trauma to the skull, not with vertical falls onto the feet.

 

Option D. Depressed fracture skull + Cervical spine injury: Depressed fractures are usually due to direct blows to the head, which is less likely in a person landing on their feet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ring # (A Fissured # in posterior fossa around foramen magnum) Accompanied by compression # of vertebrae

 

Causes: Fall from a height (‘feet / buttocks first’ impact); Severe blow on vertex; Heavy blow underneath the occiput or chin.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 247

choices.text: Oblique bullet wound
Fall from height
Sharp weapon

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting a medico-legal autopsy on a deceased individual whose skull exhibits a distinctive linear fracture with beveled edges. The skull exhibits typical findings of gutter fracture. What is the most likely mechanism for the gutter fracture in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oblique bullet wound.

 

Option A:

 

A gutter fracture is a specific type of skull fracture that occurs when a bullet strikes the skull at an oblique angle, creating a linear groove. The beveled edges of the fracture indicate the direction of the bullet's path. This type of injury is typical of a grazing bullet wound where the projectile skims the surface of the skull, displacing bone along its trajectory without penetrating deeply into the cranial cavity.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fall from height: A fall from height is more likely to cause linear, comminuted, or depressed fractures depending on the point of impact but not specifically a gutter fracture.

 

Option C. Sharp weapon: This would typically cause a penetrating injury or a laceration rather than a gutter fracture.

 

Option D. Osteoporosis: While osteoporosis can lead to increased susceptibility to fractures, it does not cause a specific fracture pattern like a gutter fracture which is characteristic of a high-velocity impact such as a bullet wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gutter #: A Long narrow depressed # of the skull, occurs due to Bullet passing adjacent to skull.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 246

choices.text: Fracture at foramen magnum

questions.text: During a medico-legal conference, a forensic expert discusses a case involving a skull injury. They explain that the skull exhibited a characteristic fracture known as Signature Fracture. What is the Signature fracture means?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Depressed skull fracture

 

Option B:

 

Depressed fracture: When a portion of fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known as depressed fracture. It is also called ‘fracture a la signature’ (signature fracture), as the shape often points towards the shape of the offending weapon. They are caused by blows with a heavy weapon having small striking surface, such as hammer, axe, brick or chopper.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Suture displacement fracture: This refers to a fracture that occurs along the sutural lines of the skull but does not necessarily involve inward indentation of the bone.

 

Option C. Countercoup injury: A contrecoup injury occurs on the side of the brain opposite to where an impact occurs, and it refers to brain injury rather than a fracture pattern.

 

Option D. Fracture at foramen magnum: This is a fracture that occurs around the large opening at the base of the skull and does not relate to the signature aspect of a depressed fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Depressed # (signature #)

 

  • Due to Heavy object with small striking surface area (e.g. hammer)
  • Fractured bone displaced inwards
  • Usually both the tables of the skull are fractured
  • Depressed # is also called signature # because sometimes the shape of the # resembles the striking surface of weapon

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 245

questions.text: During the autopsy, the forensic expert observes a distinct pattern of wounds on the neck of a deceased individual. These wounds appear shallow and hesitantly self-inflicted, with evidence of hesitation and uncertainty during the act. what is the significance of such hesitation wounds?

Ans. B) Suicide

Hesitation cuts/tentative cuts - They are parallel superficial cuts suggestive of suicidal motive, seen in the vital parts of the body such as neck, wrists, etc. They are inflicted by the victim, prior to the final fatal deep cut e.g.  suicidal cut-throat wound.

questions.text: During the autopsy of a deceased individual, the medical officer observes specific injuries on the body, particularly on the hands and forearms. These injuries appear as abrasions, lacerations, or contusions and are consistent with defensive actions, such as shielding or resisting an attack. What is the significance of these defense wounds on a deceased body?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Murder

 

Explanation:

 

Defense wounds: These are incised wounds seen on a victim’s forearms and hands, while the Victim tries to protect himself. They are suggestive of assault with a sharp weapon; hence on a dead body indicate murder. Defence wounds are of two types:

 

  1. Active Defence Wounds: When victim attempts to grab the weapon by its blade
  2. Passive Defence Wounds: When Victim just takes the weapon on his parts in order to protect himself from the attack.

 

The below image shows passive defence wound

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Defense wounds, characterized by injuries on the hands and forearms that result from defensive actions, are often observed in cases of homicide. These wounds indicate that the deceased individual attempted to protect themselves or resist an attack. In a forensic context, the presence of defense wounds is a significant indicator that the cause of death may be murder, as they suggest external violence or aggression.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family members. They report that he was assaulted by a neighbor during a dispute. On examination, you, the casualty medical officer, note that the patient has sustained fractures to his middle tooth and exhibits lacerations around his mouth. There is no evidence of head injury, and the patient is hemodynamically stable. Considering the patient condition, how would you classify the nature of this injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Grievous Hurt

 

Option B:

 

Any fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth is always a Grievous Hurt. Since fracture of tooth has occurred in the question, so it is a Grievous hurt.

 

Grievous Hurt (Defined in 320 IPC)

 

  1. Emasculation
  2. Permanent privation of sight of either eye
  3. Permanent privation of hearing of either ear.
  4. Privation of any member of joint
  5. Destruction or permanent impairment of power of any member or joint.
  6. Permanent disfiguration of head or face.
  7. Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  8. Any hurt which
  1. which endangers life (Dangerous Injury) or
  2. which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain or
  3. unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for a period of 20 days.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Simple Hurt: There is no specific definition of simple hurt. Any hurt which is not a Grievous Hurt as defined in 320 IPC is a simple hurt.

 

Option C. Dangerous injury: It is a special type of Grievous Hurt in which the life of the person is also endangered (clause 8 (a).

 

Option D. Assault: It is an attempt to use criminal force against someone e.g. Threat. It is defined in section 351 IPC. Only Attempt is sufficient to be considered as assault. Actual hurt might not have occurred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clauses of grievous hurt -

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to a community health center after a workplace accident. As the attending medical officer, you observe that a portion of his skin and underlying tissue on the forearm has been forcibly torn away. This injury appears ragged and irregular, with varying depths and contours. Based on your examination and the mechanism of injury, you are considering the classification of this wound. How would you categorize this avulsion type of injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laceration

 

Option C:

 

Avulsion refers to the forcible tearing away of skin and other tissues, often resulting in a ragged and irregular wound. This type of injury is classified as a laceration. Lacerations are characterized by irregular, torn margins and are often associated with crushing or tearing forces. The scenario described is typical of an avulsion injury, which fits the description of a laceration.

 

 

Image shows Flaying

 

Stretch laceration: Due to grinding compression by a weight over the body (e.g. Kicking, wheel of a heavy vehicle passing over the limb). A flap of the skin is produced, which is peeled off the underlying bone or deep facia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chop wound: A chop wound is typically deeper, caused by a heavy, sharp-edged object. It has a certain regularity and cleanness to the wound edges, unlike the irregularity of an avulsion.

 

Option B. Incised wound: Incised wounds are clean cuts caused by sharp-edged objects like knives or glass. They are characterized by neat, linear edges, which is not consistent with the irregular, torn appearance of an avulsion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avulsion (Shearing laceration): This is also caused in  a  similar  manner  as  a stretch laceration but the force involved is much more severe and the area involved is comparatively larger. There is separation of the skin from the underlying tissues over a relatively large area that is also called FLAYING. This is characteristic of run over accidents.

 

 Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 191

questions.text: During an autopsy at a medical college hospital, you, a forensic expert, are examining the body of a 40-year-old man who was found in an alleyway. Among various injuries, you notice a specific wound on the victim's arm. This wound is irregular, with uneven margins and varying depths. Notably, you observe strands of connective tissue, blood vessels, and nerves that appear to bridge across the base and sides of the wound. These findings are critical to your assessment and report. What type of wound typically presents with such tissue bridges?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laceration

 

Explanation:

 

Features of lacerated wound:

 

  1. Swallow Tails: The margins of lacerated wound may show tearing of the extremities at angles diverging from the main laceration, the so-called ‘swallow tails.
  2. Abrasion or bruising in the margins due to blunt force
  3. Tissue Bridges: Depth of the wound presents bridges of irregularly torn fibrous tissue, blood vessels and nerves, etc.
  4. Soiling of the wound by mud, sand, vegetation, hair, fibers, etc.
  5. Less Bleeding as compared to incised wound: Lacerated wounds do not  bleed  much  as  the  vessels  are  crushed and torn but not cut evenly, thus facilitating hemostasis  to  some  extent.
  6. Crushed hair bulb: Lacerations over the hairy areas will show hair bulbs crushed

 

The above features helps to differentiate lacerated wound from Incised wound, especially in cases of “Incised looking lacerated wound”

 

The below image shows an “Incised looking lacerated wound”. Tissue bridges confirm that it is a lacerated wound.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laceration can be differentiated from incised wounds by following:

 

  1. Due to blunt force, there is usually associated abrasions and contusions in the margins
  2. Depth of the wound presents bridges of irregularly torn tissue, blood vessels and nerves, etc.

 

Note - An opposite variety is Lacerated looking incised wound:  It is an incised wound, which looks like lacerated wound. It occurs in areas where skin folds are loose, like in axilla, scrotum etc. Here even an injury produced by sharp weapon appears as if it has irregular margins.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 191-192

questions.text: In the forensic department of a district hospital, a medical officer is examining the body of a 30-year-old woman who was reportedly involved in a violent altercation. Among the multiple injuries, one particular wound draws your attention. Located on the victim's back, this wound is deep and narrow with a characteristic 'fish tailing' appearance at one end, suggestive of a specific mechanism of injury. This morphological feature is critical for the medical officer's assessment and subsequent report. Based on your knowledge of forensic medicine, which type of wound is typically associated with 'fish tailing'?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stab wound

 

Explanation:

 

Fish tailing is produced in stab wound due to single edged weapon. In a single edged knife, the wound is usually Tear drop or wedge shape. However sometimes characteristic ‘Fish tailing’ phenomena is seen. This is produced by the blunt edge of the weapon, which sometimes causes a split which appears like a fish tail.

a: Corresponds to Sharp edge of weapon;

b, c, and d: Corresponds to the blunt edge of weapon

 

Educational Objective :

 

Shape of stab wound in relation to shape of weapon

 

  1. Single edged knife -  As described above (Tear drop or wedge shape or ‘Fish  tailing’)
  2. Double-edged knife: The wound would be spindle shaped or elliptical
  3. Nail, screw-driver: the wound would be circular shaped

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 200

questions.text: A forensic expert is evaluating a victim with a suspected firearm injury at a district hospital. Upon examination, a singular penetrating wound with a surrounding zone of stippling is noted on the victim's torso. There is no soot deposition or muzzle imprint, but the stippling pattern around the wound is clear and distinct. Based on the observed wound characteristics, what is the most likely distance from which the shot was fired?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intermediate range

 

Option B:

 

In the image, around the firearm wound, only Tattooing is present. There is no blackening or singeing. This is characteristic of intermediate range (2-4 m).

 

The minimal distance at which shot mass begins to spread is extremely variable. It may be one meter with sawed off shotgun but is usually about two metres with cylinder bore guns and four metres with full choke guns.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Close Range: Burning, blackening and tattooing are present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent), but in the question only tattooing is present.

 

Option C. Point Blank: It refers to extremely close range, but not in contact. So, the features are similar to close range.

 

Option D. Distant Range: Neither of three features (singeing, blackening and tattooing) are present in distant range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact (tight contact): Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Contact (Close Range contact / Point Blank / Loose contact / Near contact#): Burning blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range / Near range#/ Medium Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range / Long Range: None of these present around the wound.

 

#Near Contact and Near range are different

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 219

choices.text: Presence of gunpowder on hand
No sign of struggle

questions.text: As a forensic expert conducting an autopsy on a gunshot victim, you must determine the manner of death. The body has multiple gunshot wounds. During the examination, you also assess for the presence of gunpowder residue on the victim's hands and look for other signs that might indicate a struggle or defense wounds. What forensic evidence is most suggestive that the gunshot wounds could be of homicidal rather than suicidal origin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple gunshot wounds

 

Option A:

 

Multiple gunshot wounds are more suggestive of a homicidal origin, as it is uncommon for a person to inflict multiple gunshot wounds on themselves in a suicide attempt. Typically, a suicidal gunshot wound is a single, contact, or close-range wound, often located in the head, chest, or mouth, depending on the accessibility and the intent of the individual. Multiple wounds, especially in different anatomical areas, raise the suspicion of homicide.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Presence of gunpowder on hand: Gunpowder residue on the hand is more indicative of the individual having fired a gun and can be present in both suicidal and homicidal cases.

 

Option C. No sign of struggle: The absence of a struggle might be seen in both homicidal and suicidal deaths, although its presence may suggest a defensive action in a homicide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following are a few ways to differentiate murder from suicide

questions.text: During a post-mortem examination, a forensic expert is faced with a challenge. The victim had undergone extensive surgical intervention prior to death in an attempt to correct damage caused by a gunshot. This surgery has altered the original gunshot wounds, making it difficult to distinguish between the entry and exit sites. In forensic terminology, this complicating factor is referred to as what phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kennedy phenomenon

 

Option A:

 

Kennedy phenomenon: A surgical intervention of firearm wound, hence rendering the wound difficult to interpret during autopsy as happened in Kennedy’s case. Surgical intervention may make interpretation of gunshot wounds difficult as a result of obliteration or alteration of wounds.

 

For example, chest tube insertion at the site of entry wound or craniotomy in case of firearm injury to the head may alter wound track.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. McNaughton phenomenon: This is not a recognized term associated with altered gunshot wounds in forensic medicine.

 

Option C. Ricochet phenomenon: This refers to a bullet or other projectile that rebounds, bounces, or skips off a surface rather than penetrating it, which is not related to the alteration of wounds by medical procedures.

 

Option D. Alec Jeffrey phenomenon: Alec Jeffreys is known for his pioneering work on DNA profiling, not for gunshot wound characteristics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Kennedy phenomenon occurs when medical intervention, such as surgery, alters the characteristics of gunshot wounds, making it difficult to distinguish between entry and exit wounds during a post-mortem examination.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 231

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining a victim of a firearm injury during an autopsy. The expert finds remnants of material used in the ammunition that is not typically found in handguns or rifles. This material is known to be associated specifically with shotgun cartridges. What is this component of shotgun ammunition that helps to separate the charge and ensure consistent firing patterns, which is not commonly found in other types of firearms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wads

 

Option D:

 

Wad is present only in the cartridge of Shot Gun.

 

  1. The word 'wad' means a bundle of soft and light material used to keep things in place. It may be made up of card board/plastic/paper, etc
  2. it can hardly cause any serious injury.
  3. Its diameter is slightly more than the bore of the gun so that it completely seals the cartridge gunpowder and escaping gases from disturbing the shot charge.
  4. It is present only in Shot Gun Cartridge. It can be placed between Gun Powder and pellets or above the pellets.
  5. Use of wad:
    • It allows optimum pressure to develop.
    • Helps in lubrication
    • Prevents the escape of gases
  6. Wads can go up to 6 meters

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gun powder: This is a common propellant used in all types of firearms, not exclusive to shotguns.

 

Option B. Primer: This is part of the ignition system in all types of cartridge-based firearms and is not specific to shotguns.

 

Option C. Projectile: Projectiles are the objects propelled towards the target and can be bullets in handguns and rifles, or pellets and slugs in shotguns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wads are components found specifically in shotgun shells. They are used to separate the powder from the shot pellets and can also act to compress the shot charge, ensuring a consistent pattern when the shot is fired. Wads are not typically found in cartridges for handguns or rifles, which do not require a material to separate pellets or to pattern the shot.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 234
